title: Rick Fehr
text:
Richard Elliott Fehr (born August 28, 1962) is an American <a href="professional%20golfer">professional golfer</a> who has played on the <a href="PGA%20Tour">PGA Tour</a> and the <a href="Nationwide%20Tour">Nationwide Tour</a>.
Fehr was born in <a href="Seattle%2C%20Washington">Seattle, Washington</a> and grew up in the state of <a href="Washington%20%28U.S.%20state%29">Washington</a>. As a teenager, Fehr won the Washington State Junior and PGA National Junior tournaments in 1979. He attended <a href="Brigham%20Young%20University">Brigham Young University</a> in <a href="Provo%2C%20Utah">Provo, Utah</a> and was a member of the <a href="golf">golf</a> team. He was a two-time All-American while at BYU and won numerous amateur tournaments, including the 1982 <a href="Western%20Amateur">Western Amateur</a>. He was the low amateur at both <a href="Masters%20Tournament">The Masters</a> and the <a href="U.S.%20Open%20%28golf%29">U.S. Open</a> in 1984. Fehr turned pro in 1984 after earning his degree in finance; he joined the PGA Tour in 1985.
Fehr won two PGA Tour events: the 1986 <a href="B.C.%20Open">B.C. Open</a> and the 1994 <a href="Walt%20Disney%20World/Oldsmobile%20Classic">Walt Disney World/Oldsmobile Classic</a>. He finished runner-up in a PGA Tour event (2nd or T-2) nine times and had 41 top-10 finishes. His best finish in a <a href="Men%27s%20major%20golf%20championships">major championship</a> was a T-9 at the 1985 <a href="U.S.%20Open%20%28golf%29">U.S. Open</a>.
Fehr now earns his living as Director of Instruction at Aldarra Golf Club.
Professional wins (3).
PGA Tour wins (2).
PGA Tour playoff record (0–4)

"Note: Fehr never played in <a href="The%20Open%20Championship">The Open Championship</a>."<br>
